definitions.definition: to give somebody/something a particular name; to use a particular name or title when you are talking to somebody
definitions.sensetop: call somebody/something + nounbe called + nouncall somebody/something after somebody/somethingcall somebody/something by something

examples.text: They decided to call the baby Mary.
His name's Hiroshi but everyone calls him Hiro.
What's her sister called?
I don't know anyone called Scott.
I've forgotten what the firm you work for is called.
What's it called again? Oh yes, a router.
to be **commonly/often called** something
This group of artists and poets is **sometimes called** the New York School.
They called their first daughter after her grandmother.
The cheese is called after the town of the same name.
We call each other by our first names here.
The plant is called by different names in different parts of the country.
His friends affectionately call him ‘Bear’.
We usually call her by her nickname.
What do they call that new fabric?
She is writing a novel, tentatively called ‘My Future’.
The area was formerly called West Meadow.
The plant is variously called ‘cow parsley’ and ‘Queen Anne's lace’.
The prison is euphemistically called a ‘rehabilitation centre’.
The system is officially called the NPV System.

definitions.definition: to phone somebody
definitions.sensetop: call somebody/something to do somethingcall to do somethingcall somebody/something

examples.text: I'll call again later.
I got a message to **call home** immediately.
I called the office to tell them I'd be late.
People called to ask how they could help.
My brother called me from Spain last night.
Call us toll-free on this number.
Call 0800 33344 for a free copy.

definitions.definition: to ask somebody/something to come quickly to a particular place by phoning
definitions.sensetop: call somebody/somethingcall something for somebodycall somebody somethingcall somebody/something to something

examples.text: Someone **called the police**.
to call an ambulance/a doctor
I'll call a taxi for you.
I'll call you a taxi.
Fire crews were called to the building at 9 p.m.
The doctor has been called to an urgent case.

definitions.definition: to describe somebody/something in a particular way; to consider somebody/something to be something
definitions.sensetop: call somebody/something + nouncall yourself + nouncall somebody/something + adj.

examples.text: I wouldn't call German an easy language.
Are you calling me a liar?
She now calls Southern California home *(= she lives there)*.
He was in the front room, or the lounge or whatever you want to call it.
I make it ten pounds forty-three you owe me. Let's call it ten pounds.
They call themselves ‘The Gang’.
Would you call it blue or green?
You could hardly call the show perfect, but it was successful.

definitions.definition: to claim that you are a particular type of person, especially when other people question whether this is true

examples.text: Call yourself a friend? So why won't you help me, then?
She's no right to call herself a feminist.

definitions.definition: to shout or say something loudly to attract somebody’s attention
definitions.sensetop: call (out) to somebody (for something)call (out) to somebody to do somethingcall somethingcall out (something) + speech

examples.text: I thought I heard somebody calling.
She called out to her father for help.
Someone called to him to wait.
examples.contextForm: call (out) to somebody to do something

examples.text: Did somebody call my name?
People in the audience called out requests.
‘See you later!’ she called.
He called for help, but no one could hear.
She called out in pain.
‘Don't forget what I said!’ she called after him.
He called out a warning from the kitchen.

definitions.definition: to ask somebody to come by shouting or speaking loudly

examples.text: Will you call the kids in for lunch?
He heard me call him and came to the door.
Did you call?

definitions.definition: to order somebody to come to a place
definitions.sensetop: be called + adv./prep.be called to do somethingcall somebody

examples.text: Several candidates were called for a second interview.
The ambassador was called back to London by the prime minister.
He felt called to the priesthood *(= had a strong feeling that he must become a priest)*.
You may be called to give evidence.
She was called to testify before a Senate subcommittee.
The defence says it plans to call four witnesses.

definitions.definition: to order something to happen; to announce that something will happen

examples.text: to **call a meeting/strike**
The prime minister has **called an election** for 8 June.

definitions.definition: to make a short visit to a person or place
definitions.sensetop: call on somebodycall to do something

examples.text: I'll call round and see you on my way home.
Let's call on John.
He was out when I called to see him.
We called but they were out.
She said she was very lonely and it was kind of them to call on her.
Could you call by later today?
I called round at the house to check how things were.

definitions.definition: to make the noise that is typical for it

examples.text: The cuckoo called across the trees to its mate.

definitions.definition: to predict what the result of something will be

examples.text: It's a very open game that is very hard to call.
to be difficult/impossible to call
The result of this election is going to be **too close to call**.
Most media pundits called it for the Conservatives.

definitions.definition: to say which side of a coin you think will face upwards after it is thrown

examples.text: to **call heads/tails**

definitions.definition: to shout out the steps for people performing a square dance or country dance
to remember somebody/something

examples.text: She couldn't call to mind where she had seen him before.

definitions.definition: to remind you of somebody/something

examples.text: The painting brings to mind some of Picasso's early works.

definitions.definition: to tell somebody to do what they are threatening to do, because you believe that they will not be cruel or brave enough to do it

examples.text: She was tempted to call his bluff, hardly able to believe he’d carry out his threat.

definitions.definition: to make use of something

examples.text: Chess is a game that calls into play all your powers of concentration.

definitions.definition: to doubt something or make others doubt something

examples.text: His honesty has never been called into question.

definitions.definition: to decide or agree to stop doing something

examples.text: After forty years in politics I think it's time for me to call it a day *(= to retire)*.

definitions.definition: to agree to end a contest, argument, etc. because both sides seem equal
to decide to stop doing something
to use offensive words about somebody

examples.text: Stop calling me names!

definitions.definition: to be the person who controls a situation
to say exactly what you think without trying to hide your opinion

examples.text: I believe in calling a spade a spade.

definitions.definition: to say or decide that it is time for something to finish
to make somebody explain a mistake, etc. because they are responsible for it
to ask people in a meeting to be quiet so that the meeting can start or continue
to order somebody to obey the formal rules of a meeting; to start a formal meeting

examples.text: The argument continued until the chairman called them both to order.
The president brought the meeting to order at 9.15 a.m.
As the meeting was brought to order, the councillor immediately stood and began to protest.

definitions.definition: the person who provides the money for something can also control how it is spent
called to see somebody in authority because you have done something wrong

examples.text: I got called on the carpet for being late.

definitions.definition: used to say that you should not criticize somebody for a fault that you have yourself
used instead of a name that you cannot remember

examples.text: She's just gone out with old what-d'you-call-him.

wordOrigin: late Old English ceallian, from Old Norse kalla ‘summon loudly’.
